Addressed your comment. Thanks

I don't like this as its own class of thing. It's a property of of a liquid-based system that is a cooling system. So if we're trying to maintain a taxonomy in the interface name, then how about something like a interface or property in `xyz.openbmc_project.Cooling.Zone`, or perhaps `xyz.openbmc_project.Sensor.Leak`?
Done
a leak?   missing detector?
I am specifically referring to a leak in conceptual terms, added some info on value for better clarification.
Done
digital or discrete?
Added some info on value for better clarification.

the detector is to enable taking action vs taking action such as closing a valve right?

oh it looks like you are describing proposed actions to take when monitoring but didn't transition the requirements to be a monitoring application.

after reading the complete file it seems like you are combining the monitoring exposing the state of the sensor with the reaction such as initiating power off.
These are generic requirements and not in terms of specific implementation details. The design maps these requirements to how they would be fulfilled.
Updated this requirement lately. Let me know if there are still any questions.
this would be health of the sensor?
Yes. This is covered in the D-Bus interfaces section.

As mentioned in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/74022, that design and this design are pretty similar. 

I think this cable data would fit in entity-manager, in the config file of whichever FRU the GPIO is on.  You'd need some daemon to do the presence detect and put something onto D-Bus that EM could probe, so it could create the cable inventory interfaces.

> I think this cable data would fit in entity-manager, in the config file of whichever FRU the GPIO is on.  

Yes, this design had a dependency on another design for this particular aspect. My ultimate goal was to move the cable GPIO information into the entity manager (as it will be done by other design) and only keep the Inventory Item-related dependency in this configuration. I can update this config to reflect that.

> You'd need some daemon to do the presence detect and put something onto D-Bus that EM could probe, so it could create the cable inventory interfaces.

That would be handled by https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/74022, i.e. it would do presence detect for fixed hardware inventory (for example gpio for all cables) and create inventory interfaces. The purpose of this daemon is to check the inventory against the runtime configuration (for example, what cables are expected to be connected) and generate alerts if any items are missing.
Done

Ignoring the Target keyword for a moment, I think this could all be defined in entity-manager as it describes hardware.  Assuming EM ends up creating the cable object, you could use the same 'physical topology' (there's a design doc for it) tricks to automatically add associations.

The major reason is the JSON config file method may break when you have to support more than 1 system out of the same flash image.

As for the target, in EM you may not want to hardcode a target name, but you could just make it into an enum, like: Action: HardPowerOffRack.

> Ignoring the Target keyword for a moment, I think this could all be defined in entity-manager as it describes hardware.  Assuming EM ends up creating the cable object, you could use the same 'physical topology' (there's a design doc for it) tricks to automatically add associations.

Yes, as you mentioned my intent was to move this to EM as well once the gpio based HW inventory design was finalized. But i am fine to make that change now. Will add details on what Detector related configuration can be exposed based on cable PROBES, although cable DBUS objects for PROBE conditions will be defined by the GPIO based HW inventory design. 

> 
> The major reason is the JSON config file method may break when you have to support more than 1 system out of the same flash image.

Sounds good.

> 
> As for the target, in EM you may not want to hardcode a target name, but you could just make it into an enum, like: Action: HardPowerOffRack.

Sure.
Done

the cooling zone?   I'd expect the detector to establish the severity.   the impact of loosing the cooling zone and isolatio might drive how quickly you initiate shutdown/timeout or hard off )if you even have shutoff control)

Normally, detectors are placed in certain vicinity mechanically to create zones. 

The second approach is just an alternative. The first approach is the one which will be used and let client decide on how they want to treat severity, they can either rely on zones or specific detectors.
Updated the design lately, so this might not apply. Please check it and let me know. Thanks

FWIW, the Nvidia reference for this does everything in dbus-sensors (GPIO based and ADC based);  That's not to say it's better to organize things in new repos, but it does exist, so clearly dbus-sensors is one place this problem can be solved.

There's a significant update to Redfish coming to solve a lot of these interface issues that wasn't really mentioned in this design, and I don't think can be mentioned at the moment.  We were waiting for the Redfish schemas for leak detection to be published (because you can't talk about redfish schemas until they're released).

This design skirted around this by just not being complete, which I guess works?  But we should complete it before we approve new repos.

> FWIW, the Nvidia reference for this does everything in dbus-sensors (GPIO based and ADC based);  That's not to say it's better to organize things in new repos, but it does exist, so clearly dbus-sensors is one place this problem can be solved.

Sure, i have added some info into the TOF issue as what i can see end up becoming part of something like phosphor-liquid-cooling in future. You can look at that and see if it makes sense for a different repo.

> 
> There's a significant update to Redfish coming to solve a lot of these interface issues that wasn't really mentioned in this design, and I don't think can be mentioned at the moment.  We were waiting for the Redfish schemas for leak detection to be published (because you can't talk about redfish schemas until they're released).

I have requested access to Redfish github to see whats being proposed, will check it.

> 
> This design skirted around this by just not being complete, which I guess works?  But we should complete it before we approve new repos.

The current design serves the redfish requirements of whats publicly available. But we can definitely add any new/missing requirements. We can discuss if we should add those requirements now (if Redfish schema releases soon) or add them later (if Redfish schema release is not in near term).
The current design and implementation will be based on whats publicly available, we can extend it and add new/missing requirements when they become available.
Huh?  This is news to me.  PSUs have presence and LED status, and there's plenty of other counter examples.
I am specifically referring to sensors not being able to represent boolean values. Changed the wording to reflect so.
I suspect I understand why, but we need to enumerate WHY it would be difficult to just add the needed features here to the point that it justifies a new thing.
Added more details on this in the Alternative section.
If it's beyond the scope of the document, can we just list 74022 as a prerequisite for this being approved?

I don't think 74022 is a prerequisite for this design because leak detectors can be directly connected to the BMC or they can exist on another pluggable board/cable, just like any other hwmon or temp sensor. I added this initially to define the scope of this design, but i will better remove this to avoid any confusion.

Need way more details.
1. What hardware interfaces are supported.
2. what does "Raise alerts" mean?
Done
This needs more detail around "hot plug" requirements.  Are the leak detectors ADCs?  GPIOs?  I2c devices?
Removed this line and added details to Item#1 above.
Need more details on how a "severity level" would work with a leak.
Added some example for better clarification, but that is just an instance of a problem.
Is this design "take appropriate remediation actions"  if it's another component taking action, mention that not as a requirement.
Done
"hot plug" implies that the cable is expected to be removed and shouldn't error if it's remove.  Maybe we just call it removable?  idk.
I have removed this requirement since it was related to cable-monitor. As you suggested i would keep that design separate.

This isn't a requirement.  Need details on which properties, collections, and interfaces you're planning on implementing.

FYI, there's reference Nvidia code that does this already if you want somewhere to start from, or if you're implementing your own set of Redfish interfaces, that works too.

> This isn't a requirement.  Need details on which properties, collections, and interfaces you're planning on implementing.

I have mentioned this as a requirement because the D-Bus interfaces need to expose required info which is mappable to Leak Detection Schema. I have rephrased it for better clarification. Also added a section on what would be implemented in the BMCWeb.

> 
> FYI, there's reference Nvidia code that does this already if you want somewhere to start from, or if you're implementing your own set of Redfish interfaces, that works too.

Sounds good.
Can you wrap this so it's readable?  I get you're making a table, but it still needs to be readable in markdown.
Moved around stuff to make this look better.
Cooling zone isn't a leak detector zone.  They're different things fundamentall.
I have changed this to LeakDetectorGroup in recent patch.
Shouldn't this be Item.LeakDetector?  Cooling namespace hasn't been defined, and I don't really think it's a good idea.  A leak detector lives in two namespaces. Inventory and State.

> Shouldn't this be Item.LeakDetector?  Cooling namespace hasn't been defined, and I don't really think it's a good idea.  

I have changed the namespace to LeakDetection

> A leak detector lives in two namespaces. Inventory and State.

I am considering LeakDetector same way as sensor. As for sensors there is no explicit InventoryItem/State and sensors have their own namespace (not Inventory or State), same way i am defining a different namespace here.
Changed the namespace to State.
xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item isn't an interface?

> xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item isn't an interface?

My understanding is its an abstract interface which gets extended by specific inventory items. But on change side, i am just adding an association in it.
Abstract would imply that it should never be instantiated.

Yes, but specific inventory items, for example, board can inherit them. Here i added this to show which interfaces are being modified for the design, let me know if you want me to move this line anywhere else.
Removed this from list as its implicit.

You define an EM config below, then define a non EM config here.  You should be consistent.  If your intent is to implement this on an EM system, use EM to define your configs.

If your intent is to use phosphor-inventory-manager, use on disk configs, just be consistent.
As you suggested in another comment, i am going to drop the cable-monitor from this doc and will create a new design doc for it.
?  What does this design have to do with cables?  I suspect you need to remove mention of cables in this doc for the moment and just defer to the other doc.
Sure, removed it.
not sure what cable monitor has to do with leaks?
Removed it from here and will add a new design doc for that.
80 char widths please.  I get that's a pain.
Should we just do this in Mermaid?  We've never required ASCII art diagrams to be 80 characters wide elsewhere.

I have no strong opinions other than this diagram being hard to review in gerrit.

if mermaid makes it reviewable, great.

> this diagram being hard to review in gerrit.

Agreed.  I think we should stop doing all ASCII art diagrams.  They're all impossible to review in Gerrit.

You can read this .md file in rendered format -

Click on latest commit hash (for example, `a345e6c`) -> It takes you to https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/a345e6c207be64359ce1883387637826a7b86837 -> There click on `designs/liquid-leak-detection.md` ---will-take-to--> https://gerrit.openbmc.org/plugins/gitiles/openbmc/docs/+/a345e6c207be64359ce1883387637826a7b86837/designs/liquid-leak-detection.md.

I know its 3 step process but it shows the .md file in rendered format which is easy to read and all diagrams also shows up fine.

Gerrit is the tool we use to do code reviews.  I understand there's a number of ways I could render this in a reasonable way, including gitiles, but there's no way to leave specific comments in code review when using those tools.

Personally, I find a lot of these ascii diagrams to be less useful than the equivalent text for single-path flows like this.

> Gerrit is the tool we use to do code reviews.  I understand there's a number of ways I could render this in a reasonable way, including gitiles, but there's no way to leave specific comments in code review when using those tools.

Yaa, i understand that rendered docs doesn't let you leave comments. But normally i use that just for reading purpose.
I have tried to cut short the digram width, please see if that helps.
Changed this to mermaid.
Do we really need an explicit enable?  What function would it serve?
I missed this from an old change. Updated this to explicit Detector interface.

Might want to be a little more specific about this, because there's a lot of leak detector types.

This should probably be something like

GpioLiquidDetector.
Done

I think we have this problem other places, but I wonder if we should be making these "ActiveLow" instead of just low/high.

Might not be a problem for this.
Done

?  I can't tell if this is a pointer to another EM config entry that doesn't exist, or if this is supposed to be a type.  "Zone" as a collection of components is something we already do for fans a bit, we should model something similar.
I have changed this attribute name to Group and even for Zone i saw a similar model.

In Redfish this is generally configurable, so I suspect this should be

DefaultAction: PowerOff

"Rack power off" has no concept in openbmc, we have chassis power off and host power off.
Done

can we just call this "leak detector"

Manager is overused and isn't descriptive
I am calling this LeakManager as it encapsulates multiple LeakDetectorGroups and LeakDetectors. Will name this LeakDetectionManager, let me know if it still doesn't work.
Why not just on event?  There's other examples in dbus sensors of polling for events.
Done
nit "registers a leak" is different than "enabled"
Done
continue this with "And can't be added because A, B, C"  FWIW I agree with you, but lets get it enumerated why separation is important.
Done

That's not really what impacts is for.

If you're polling, you're adding system load.
If the leak detection system crashes and there's a leak, hardware is broken.
Done

Wouldn't (present or not-present) be a boolean value?

Aren't all values which are not analog, digital values?

> Wouldn't (present or not-present) be a boolean value?
> Aren't all values which are not analog, digital values?

Sorry i didn't understand your question. Here i am referring to a state rather than a concrete implementation of that state.
nevermind. i was just confused by describing it as a 'digital' value. It's a digital value but that description is not very specific. But that's a nit.
previously you said a leak is a 'digital' value with two states (present/non-present). Where are the attributes coming from now?
Please refer to the example in the next section which is one of the possible ways.

Isn't every leak critical since it can spread? Unless the chassis is completely watertight, it will just spread everywhere, right? Nvm if i'm wrong here since i never saw one of these designs in person.

Isn't every leak critical since it can spread? Unless the chassis is completely watertight, it will just spread everywhere, right? Nvm if i'm wrong here since i never saw one of these designs in person.

Yes, you can refer to the example i mentioned as that provides some information on how a particular leak can change severity over its lifetime depending upon which detectors it hits (based on physical placement of detectors). Let me know if you still have any questions.

can't there be a event handler registered via libgpiod for the gpio edge event?
Why is there a need for polling?

Done, updated it.

FYI: We are planning to use gpioplus. Please refer https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/1285375282819104831/1285423502224003144.

why use gpioplus? It will introduce yet another inconsistency in openbmc with some repos using it and others using libgpiod. Is libgpiod really so limited that it cannot cover your use-case? Currently most daemons use libgpiod from what i've seen. It's a well tested and well documented library.

For contrast, the gpioplus is a library with barely 58 commits, which only has a single example code (which is only 34 lines of code).

This is more of an implementation question rather than a design one. Let's continue the discussion on the Discord link I shared earlier to involve a wider audience. I will mark this as resolved for now, but please let me know if you have any other questions or concerns.

Why does the design require a new repository?
Can't this be a new daemon in the dbus-sensors repo?

I have added some details in the TOF issue on what can go into a new repo https://github.com/openbmc/technical-oversight-forum/issues/41, so not just this but in general more stuff related to liquid cooling as a feature.

nah it can still go into dbus-sensors, even if it's not a sensor.

It would be too confusing to have it somewhere else. Just because the repo name does not 100% match all the daemons inside, it's not an excuse to exacerbate the repo bloat.

For entity-manager, there is also FruDevice inside that repo and i'm not aware it has caused any issues.

dbus-sensors has lots of common code related to thresholds and configuration parsing for sensors. Unless you plan to refactor all of that and put it into a common library, then how will you re-use that code?

> nah it can still go into dbus-sensors, even if it's not a sensor.
> 
> It would be too confusing to have it somewhere else. Just because the repo name does not 100% match all the daemons inside, it's not an excuse to exacerbate the repo bloat.

The reason for this is not the name of the repository itself, but rather the idea of grouping together a collection of related applications under the same repository based on what I believe could potentially be included in that repository in the future. These applications are all related to a very specific feature related to liquid cooling.

> For entity-manager, there is also FruDevice inside that repo and i'm not aware it has caused any issues.

> dbus-sensors has lots of common code related to thresholds and configuration parsing for sensors. Unless you plan to refactor all of that and put it into a common library, then how will you re-use that code?
 
Regarding where this code should go, it is more of an organizational question that we need to address. We have an open TOF issue for this topic and I will also start a thread on Discord to discuss some of the important open topics, including this one.
Changed the repo to dbus-sensors.

Can you explain what is a GPIO based detector? Currently leak sensors have several different output types including frequency, voltage and resistance etc. I think we would want take a look at different types and have a design that has the flexibility to be extended the the different type of leak sensors.

The sensors we are using give a binary "liquid detected" signal.  If someone wants to support other types of sensors they can extend this design, right?  Is there anything you see in the design that seems to make it difficult for other sensor types to be supported?

Thanks for explaining. This GPIO-based detector is a discrete sensor. Some of the other types, like frequency and resistance are all analog sensors. Leak.Detector state would possibly base of threshold configuration. Yes, the design can be extended later.
Marking this comment resolved.
I'd prefer this to be written with mermaid and not ascii art.
Done
What is a "rope" and how is it related to leak detection?  Seems like the first (and only) time you've mentioned it.

I used the word "rope" to make it clear and specific to LeakSensor. I could have also used the word "suffix" as "cable," but "cable" is often interpreted more broadly as any type of connectivity cable.

I see some products using this term, for example, https://www.chatsworth.com/en-us/products/power-monitoring-security/accessories/environmental-sensors/leak-detection-sensor-rope
Changed to LeakSensingCable and also raised a gerrit PR for EM schema change and added reference to design.

I suspect we should add a json-schema for this also?  What are valid "DefaultAction"? 

How do you specify which chassis to power off if there are multiple of them?  I thought the Ventura can manage N different chassis.

> I suspect we should add a json-schema for this also? 

I submitted a pull request for a change to the JSON schema and added it to the design document.


> What are valid "DefaultAction"? 

I defined an enumeration for DefaultActions in the schema. Currently, I can think of two valid actions: RackPowerOff and ChassisPowerOff.

> 
> How do you specify which chassis to power off if there are multiple of them?  I thought the Ventura can manage N different chassis.

For Ventura, only the RackPowerOff operation is applicable. Therefore, this new operation would be relevant to define for RackManager.
Done
This isn't true since phosphor-gpio-monitor primarily triggers systemd targets.
Done
I would clarify only GPIO-based is supported as the current design
Already mentioned in the design's "Background and References" section. Are you suggesting to add that to PR description as well?
